Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Fast Surrogate Modeling for Design under Uncertainty of Complex Engineering Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program grant will establish an integrated research and education program motivated by the challenges associated with the development of predictive, simulation-based methods for the design and optimization of complex engineering system. Complex engineering systems often involve multiple physical phenomena at multiple scales. Such systems dominate current engineering interests, for example, as in the design and manufacturing of materials and energy storage systems. The dynamics of these systems are intrinsically variable due to, for instance, material properties or manufacturing imperfections, so that there is an imperative need to quantify the impact of such uncertainties for accurate performance prediction and design optimization. To this end and with the objective of advancing the current simulation technologies available for design and optimization, this award supports the development of a set of novel theories, algorithms, and software tools for fast characterization and propagation of uncertainty. The increasing significance and societal impact of predictive simulation capabilities in present and future design of engineering systems will additionally form the basis of an outreach and education effort to attract and engage future generations of engineers, especially from women and underrepresented minorities, entering and studying at the University of Colorado, Boulder.

The approach for uncertainty characterization and propagation is based on new and scalable surrogate modeling  schemes, together with effective computational tools for robust design and optimization of complex engineering systems. The idea of surrogate modeling is to construct an approximate (but inexpensive to evaluate) representation of the mapping between the parameters of a model and the performance objectives. This surrogate model is then used for robust design, optimization, sensitivity analysis, or decision making. To enable fast construction of surrogate models, novel deterministic and random sampling schemes along with model reduction approaches will be developed, in the context of sparse and low-rank approximations. The key to the scalability of the new algorithms is that they effectively and automatically identify the lower-dimensional manifold on which the possibly high-dimensional or non-smooth system solution exists. The surrogate modeling tools will be employed to better predict the reliability of lithium ion battery cells, and to facilitate the uncertainty-aware design of their electrodes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In many complex engineering applications, the impact of uncertainties due to intrinsic variabilities or incomplete understanding of the underlying physical laws must be quantified to build computer models that can be reliably utilized for analysis and design. Fundamental difficulties, however, arise when (i) the number of independent uncertain variables is large, where standard techniques encounter an exponential growth of computational complexity known as curse-of-dimensionality, or (ii) the model itself must be extracted from often noisy response measurements. Within the context of surrogate modeling, this project has tackled these issues through the development of transformative algorithms and effective numerical tools based on sparse and low-rank approximation techniques. Surrogate modeling refers to the construction of an approximate, but cheap to evaluate, representation of the mapping between a model's inputs and the quantities of interest (QoI?s). Such a model is constructed a priori based on full model simulations and is used to rapidly generate predictions of the system state, QoI statistics, and global/local sensitivity information, among others.  

To address the issue of curse-of-dimensionality, two research directions were pursued and completed. In the first approach, novel sparse approximation techniques in the context of compressed sensing were developed for scenarios in which the QoI is represented in a high-order multi-variate polynomial basis. The key to the success of these strategies is (i) the utility of the gradient samples of the QoI with respect to the model inputs and (ii) optimal random and deterministic sampling strategies that efficiently explore the input space. The second approach focused on low-rank approximation via multi-fidelity modeling. The idea behind multi-fidelity modeling is to rely primarily on low-fidelity (cheaper but less accurate) models of a target high-fidelity (expensive but accurate) model to (i) efficiently explore the design/uncertainty space and (ii) generate an approximation rule to achieve solutions with accuracies close to that of the high-fidelity model. In particular, the work performed was focused on generating a reduced basis for approximating the solution of interest with the goal of answering the following question for the first time: How can one ensure, with relatively small cost, that a given low-fidelity model leads to an accurate multi-fidelity approximation? To this end, a practical a posteriori error estimate was developed, and its efficacy was illustrated on applications in solid and fluid mechanics.  The extension and application of this multi-fidelity strategy to in situ compression of large ensembles of high-dimensional simulation data was also carried out. 

A second main research thrust of this project was related to the development of stable sparse approximation schemes for data-driven modeling and recovery of governing equations to non-linear dynamical systems. The work was motivated by the fact that often complex physical phenomena cannot be fully described by equations, e.g., partial differential equations, or even no mathematical models are available for the physics at hand, e.g., in biological systems. However, data, often noisy, can be observed from the dynamical system. The question is then, how can this data be used in a systematic way to generate approximate models that can be used for predictions of the system at hand? To address this question, a class of methods rely on compressed sensing to identify a sparse basis representation of the nonlinear fluxes -- therefore the governing equation -- using measurements of the states. The current formulation, however, suffers from instability due to large measurement noise and ill-conditioning of the basis matrix as it generally does not lend itself to conditions, e.g., restricted isometry property, required for compressed sensing to be successful. To address this issue, novel preconditioning, iteratively re-weighted regularization, and denoising strategies have been developed. Numerical experiments on several non-linear dynamical systems have illustrated the superiority of these approaches over the state-of-the-art techniques.
